person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_035.name: Homer
person_035.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

person_138.name: Aristotle
person_138.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

person_508.name: Lucretius
person_508.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

person_448.name: DiodorusSiculus
person_448.description: Of Sicily was an ancient Greek historian. He is known for writing the monumental universal history Bibliotheca historica, in forty books, fifteen of which survive intact, between 60 and 30 BCE.

person_401.name: JuliusCaesar
person_401.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_510.name: Strabo
person_510.description: Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_860.name: Hesiod
person_860.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

person_062.name: GeorgiusAgricola
person_062.description: Physician who studied the minerals and mining practices in Saxony and surrounding areas. His influential book De re metallica (1556) was published postumously.

person_1068.name: Alonso BarbaAlvaro
person_1068.description: a secular Catholic priest and metallurgist born in Lepe , a town in the province of Seville, in Andalusia, Spain. He published Arte de los Metales [Art of metals] in Madrid in 1640 and this book was translated into English by Edward Montagu in 1670.

person_466.name: WilliamPryce
person_466.description: Cornish medic and mine owner who wrote Mineralogia Cornubiensis (1778).

person_1069.name: WilliamCookworthy
person_1069.description: an English Quaker minister, a successful pharmacist and an innovator in several fields of technology.

person_387.name: John JoachimBecher
person_387.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_470.name: Johann FriedrichHenckel
person_470.description: Prussian physician, chemist, metallurgist, and mineralogist.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of atheism following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

place_986.name: Phrygia
place_986.description: In classical antiquity, Phrygia was a kingdom in the west central part of Anatolia, in what is now Asian Turkey, centered on the Sangarios River.

place_1181.name: Crete
place_1181.description: The largest and most populous of the Greek islands. Davy refers to it as Candia, the name of the island under Venetian rule between the 13th and 17th centuries.

place_1392.name: Cyprus
place_1392.description: Cyprus is the third largest and third-most populous island in the Mediterranean. It is east of Greece, north of Egypt, south of Turkey, and west of Lebanon and Syria. Cyprus occupies an important role in Greek mythology, being the birthplace of Aphrodite and Adonis, and home to King Cinyras, Teucer and Pygmalion.

place_1085.name: Phoenicia
place_1085.description: An ancient civilization originating in the coastal strip of the Levant region of the eastern Mediterranean, primarily located in modern Lebanon.

place_1083.name: Anatolia
place_1083.description: Also known as Asia Minor. A large peninsula in West Asia it is the western-most extension of continental Asia as it borders European Turkey.

place_873.name: Iran
place_873.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_796.name: Plymouth
place_796.description: Plymouth is a port city in the south-west of England

place_013.name: St Michael's Mount
place_013.description: St Michael's Mount is a tidal island in Mount's Bay, Cornwall, with a distinct conical shape.

place_306.name: Alston Moor
place_306.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

place_1363.name: River Tees
place_1363.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_1027.name: Hungary
place_1027.description: a landlocked country in Central Europe. Its capital, Budapest, is bisected by the Danube River.

place_1008.name: Transylvania
place_1008.description: Transylvania is a historical and cultural region in Central Europe, encompassing central Romania.

place_1028.name: Argyll
place_1028.description: a historic county and registration county of western Scotland.

place_079.name: Cumberland
place_079.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

place_1359.name: Northumberland
place_1359.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.
